thought: The content of the website seems to be imitating a security scanning process, which could be a tactic to scare users into thinking their system is compromised. The use of a phone number for assistance is suspicious and might be a sign that this website could be a scam.
There are no hyperlinks extracted from the website, which is unusual for a legitimate security service website as they typically provide additional resources or contact information through links.

thought: The certificate information shows that the website has a valid SSL certificate issued by Let's Encrypt, which is common for both legitimate and fraudulent websites. So far, the evidence points toward possible scam activity based on the content of the website, but the presence of a valid SSL certificate does not confirm a scam. The lack of hyperlinks and the suspicious nature of the content are concerning, but additional context is needed for a conclusive decision.
observation: [{'url': 'https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/its-raining-phish-and-scams-how-cloudflare-pages-dev-and-workers-dev-domains-get-abused/', 'content': 'With workers.dev, you can build your page and deploy it using your local resources. Comparing the two Cloudflare services, despite the free trial offered in workers.dev it seems pages.dev is the most abused domain, probably because of the convenience and benefit of using a Git provider like GitHub in web development.'}, {'url': 'https://www.scamvoid.net/', 'content': 'Find a list of most viewed website reports of this month. Use this service to check the online reputation of a website, check if a website is safe or a scam, check if a website is safe to buy from, check if a website is legit and trusted by other users.'}, {'url': 'https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2021/08/26/widespread-credential-phishing-campaign-abuses-open-redirector-links/', 'content': 'Microsoft has been actively tracking a widespread credential phishing campaign using open redirector links. Attackers combine these links with social engineering baits that impersonate well-known productivity tools and services to lure users into clicking. Doing so leads to a series of redirections—including a CAPTCHA verification page that ...'}, {'url': 'https://www.scam-detector.com/validator/pages-dev-review/', 'content': 'pages.dev Review. The Scam Detector website Validator gives pages.dev a medium-high trust score on the platform: 75.80.It signals that the business is best defined by the following tags: Standard. Valid. Common.. We are confident about our score as we also partner with other high-tech, fraud-prevention companies that found the same issues.'}, {'url': 'https://cybernews.com/malware/remove-windows-defender-security-warning/', 'content': 'Remove Windows Defender pop-up from Chrome. 1. Click on the three dots at the top right corner. 2. Choose "Settings". 3. Click "Advanced " in the bottom left of the window. 4. Press "Reset and clean up".'}]

By clicking submit below, you agree to our Terms of Use July 11, 2023 3 minutes read Karla Agregado As they say, when it rains, it pours. Recently, we observed more than 3,000 phishing emails containing phishing URLs abusing services at workers.dev and pages.dev domains. What is .dev Top Level Domain (TLD)? The .dev  top-level domain name is operated by Google. It is incorporated on the HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) preload list, requiring HTTPS on all .dev domains without individual HSTS enlistment. Cloudflare Pages vs Workers Both pages.dev workers.dev Abused Cloudflare Domains in Phishing Emails Phishing email mimicking financial services company: Figure 1 Phishing email with URL redirection: sondakikatokathaberleri[.]name[.]tr/hash/demo/mailer.php sondakikatokathaberleri[.]name[.]tr Figure 3.2 hxxps://tutu57tututut[.]000webhostapp[.]com/don[.]php hxxps://ancient-salad-4674.mmrctliacetgliue504[.]workers[.]dev/87c03eda-fdd4-4125-bf73-1b161178699a S URLs hxxp://a211a49a8bb35[.]pages[.]dev/ hxxps://3f303073[.]45564355zezdfxc56e667[.]pages.dev/qrdcxw52463f86302yh72-fe4367z hxxps://helpsana[.]ro/wp-hash/1/index4[.]php hxxps://1-d0asfasfjhasfa7979352jhasf.pages[.]dev/ Some Samples of Scam or Fake News URLs with a Common Domain Format hxxps://flexjobs-10.pages[.]dev/ hxxps://safe-cash90.pages[.]dev/ hxxps://cashgraber173.pages[.]dev/ hxxps://moneypro105.pages[.]dev/ Latest SpiderLabs Blogs EDR – The Multi-Tool of Security Defenses This is Part 8 in my ongoing project to cover 30 cybersecurity topics in 30 weekly blog posts. thought: The Trustwave article confirms that pages.dev, which is operated by Cloudflare, is often misused for phishing and scams. It specifically mentions how phishing emails containing URLs are abusing services at pages.dev domains. This context suggests that defender.pages.dev could indeed be part of a scam operation. Based on the content I have reviewed and the typical characteristics of scam websites, I believe I have enough information to determine if defender.pages.dev is a scam website. Yes, defender.pages.dev appears to be a scam website.

observation.reason: imitating a security scanning process using scare tactics providing a suspicious phone number for support lack of hyperlinks typically found on a legitimate security service website and context from external sources indicating that pages.dev domains are often abused for phishing and scam operations.
